pros:
There are only a few things that I truly enjoyed while I worked here. One being the students. I got to interact with so many brilliant, talented, and creative students. I came to build relationships with a few colleagues that I came to love and trust. 

Prior to covid, they'd cover all costs associated with attending conferences. That was greatly appreciated, and it allowed me an opportunity to engage with professionals from across the country.
cons: No employer is without their faults, however, what I experienced here over the years has been nothing short of traumatizing. It felt like no one truly cared about my professional development (I found one person who did), mediocre talent received promotions, and real issues are dismissed once they determine the validity of your complaint. My time here helped me learn what I do not want in my next role.

pros: Free housing Professional Development Customer Service Experience Leadership
cons: Long hours Duties can get in the way of school life if time is not managed well

review_title: Smooth Transition From Alumni to Staff, Horrible Administration
pros:
- They frequently hire Stockton graduates.
- 35hr work-week, with the option for alternative schedules in the summer.
- Vacation, sick, personal, and compensatory time are all included.
- Tuition waivers allow you to continue your education cheaply.
- Great health benefits.
cons:
- Administration is not flexible, and has a strict policy when dealing with employees who need or request hybrid or remote work (AKA, it's nonexistent).
- As a public employee, your pay can be drastically below industry standard, and raises are not based on performance. You need to apply for and validate an entirely new job/level change.
- Parking is atrocious and they refuse to fix the problem, yet constantly say they need to attract more students.
- Via mass email, they've more than once tried to keep faculty/staff from speaking out publicly against issues.

pros: No real pros at this time

review_title: It was definitely a learning experience that I wouldn't replace, but wouldn't redo.
pros: Ability to learn many job functions at once. Pay was significantly higher than most residential life positions. Great staff at that time. Budgets were good so professional development was always an option.
cons: Senior management was horrible. There was no direction from the top down and it became frustrating and made the position unbearable. Several of my colleagues and I left within a 2 month period  (5 out of 7). Very high school mindset and no loyalty among professionals.

review_title: Faculty in my program are unfairly saddled with administrative tasks without proper recognition or remuneration.
pros: Stockton has a very strong union and decent salaries. There is a lot of faculty-to-faculty support. Faculty senate is respected and professional.
cons: Poor leadership at the dean level in most divisions. Faculty are not fairly recognized and remunerated. The faculty and administration have real problems with gender bias -- it's like the 1950s.

review_title: Working at Stockton was a good experience overall.
pros: Because Stockton is a college, they understand the challenges inherent in balancing a work and school schedule.
cons: None, really.  Except that the parking is insane during the week, making it difficult for you if your shift starts in the afternoon.

job_title: Professional Services Specialist, IV in Galloway, NJ
pros: Friendly work environment with co-workers and staff that work together to achieve a common goal.
cons: Parking on campus is a nightmare if you work second shift. Shift hours can make it difficult to plan personal life. Shift schedule changes often throughout the semester as well based on University events which also affect your sleep schedule. Another con is too many group email responses that clog your inbox.
